channel.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
channel.description: Going to try to teach myself how to efficiently use and successfully use JDBC with SQL and was wondering if anyone has any advice for me while I learn it.

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:14, topic:548765”][quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=667673.msg4465696#msg4465696 date=1419971920]

Why do you split the lines at OR/AND? It makes it just more confusing. Isn’t it enough to make the split at “keywords” like WHERE, FROM, GROUP BY, HAVING, ORDER BY…?
And use this way of making multiline strings: http://stackoverflow.com/a/878704 (First code bit). Much less clutter in the code and is supposed to be as efficient as Stringbuilder in this instance.
[/quote]The comments below seem to disagree with your statement. What would make it more efficient then StringBuilder?

The compiler would make it one single string. I didn’t say more efficient, just as efficient. And the code is cleaner when you have less stuff surrounding it. The comment below agree with me.[/quote]Ok, I understand now. Was just asking because one the comments said doing something that seemed inappropriate for the task at hand.

Read full topic

And use this way of making multiline strings: http://stackoverflow.com/a/878704 (First code bit). Much less clutter in the code and is supposed to be as efficient as Stringbuilder in this instance.

The compiler would make it one single string. I didn’t say more efficient, just as efficient. And the code is cleaner when you have less stuff surrounding it. The comment below agree with me.

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Why do you split the lines at OR/AND? It makes it just more confusing. Isn’t it enough to make the split at “keywords” like WHERE, FROM, GROUP BY, HAVING, ORDER BY…?
And use this way of making multiline strings: http://stackoverflow.com/a/878704 (First code bit). Much less clutter in the code and is supposed to be as efficient as Stringbuilder in this instance.

Read full topic

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:9, topic:548765”]You have to set its value by using setString, for a start.[/quote]Either way, it doesn’t effect what I am trying to accomplish here.

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:10, topic:548765”]I don’t know if this will help you, but I have written a quick and easy wrapper class for JDBC purposes. Change the stuff you find necessary to change.

import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.Driver;
import java.sql.DriverManager;
import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.SQLException;
import java.sql.Statement;

import javax.sql.DataSource;

import com.mysql.jdbc.PreparedStatement;



public class MySQLConnector {

	static Connection con;
	
	public static void init() {
		// TODO Auto-generated constructor stub
		
		
		try {
			Class.forName("com.mysql.jdbc.Driver");
			con = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:mysql://localhost/timelister?","root","");
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		} catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}		
	}
	
	public static ResultSet get(String s, Object[] objects){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			for(int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++){
				
				statement.setObject(i + 1, objects[i]);
			}

			return statement.executeQuery();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
	
	public static ResultSet send(String s, Object[] objects){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			for(int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++){
				statement.setObject(i + 1, objects[i]);
			}

			statement.execute();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
	
	
	public static ResultSet send(String s){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			statement.execute();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
}

You want to use the get method. The parameters you exchange with “?” is just an array of objects. Just make sure to have as many parameters as "?"s.[/quote]I thank you. In the most simplistic design, this does help with the basic connection to a database. I will experience with this after I can learn syntax better.

Read full topic

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I don’t know if this will help you, but I have written a quick and easy wrapper class for JDBC purposes. Change the stuff you find necessary to change.

import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.Driver;
import java.sql.DriverManager;
import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.SQLException;
import java.sql.Statement;

import javax.sql.DataSource;

import com.mysql.jdbc.PreparedStatement;



public class MySQLConnector {

	static Connection con;
	
	public static void init() {
		// TODO Auto-generated constructor stub
		
		
		try {
			Class.forName("com.mysql.jdbc.Driver");
			con = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:mysql://localhost/timelister?","root","");
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		} catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}		
	}
	
	public static ResultSet get(String s, Object[] objects){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			for(int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++){
				
				statement.setObject(i + 1, objects[i]);
			}

			return statement.executeQuery();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
	
	public static ResultSet send(String s, Object[] objects){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			for(int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++){
				statement.setObject(i + 1, objects[i]);
			}

			statement.execute();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
	
	
	public static ResultSet send(String s){
		PreparedStatement statement;
		try {
			statement = (PreparedStatement) con.prepareStatement(s);
			statement.execute();
		    
			
		} catch (SQLException e) {
			// TODO Auto-generated catch block
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		return null;
	}
}

You want to use the get method. The parameters you exchange with “?” is just an array of objects. Just make sure to have as many parameters as "?"s.

Read full topic

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

Well, I am working with a prewritten system and I added a field within the table for MAC Addresses to be stored. Upon login, the DB is read, and here is what I am having trouble understanding.

                            [code=SQL]bldr.append("SELECT UNIX_TIMESTAMP() as now, id, type, UNIX_TIMESTAMP(expire) as expire ");
			bldr.append("FROM sanctions ");
			bldr.append("WHERE ((name = ?) ");
			bldr.append("OR (ipaddress IS NOT NULL AND ipaddress = ?)) ");
			bldr.append("AND closed = 0 ");
			bldr.append("ORDER BY id DESC");
			statement = connection.prepareStatement(bldr.toString());
			statement.setString(1, username);
			statement.setString(2, address);
			ResultSet result = statement.executeQuery(); // blocking op[/code]

I am trying to get the syntax to read the MAC address within this and I have tried several different things like:

bldr.append("SELECT UNIX_TIMESTAMP() as now, id, type, UNIX_TIMESTAMP(expire) as expire "); bldr.append("FROM sanctions "); bldr.append("WHERE ((name = ?) "); bldr.append("OR (ipaddress IS NOT NULL AND ipaddress = ?) OR (macaddress IS NOT NULL AND macaddress =?)) "); bldr.append("AND closed = 0 "); bldr.append("ORDER BY id DESC"); statement = connection.prepareStatement(bldr.toString()); statement.setString(1, username); statement.setString(2, address); ResultSet result = statement.executeQuery(); // blocking op

or this

bldr.append("SELECT UNIX_TIMESTAMP() as now, id, type, UNIX_TIMESTAMP(expire) as expire "); bldr.append("FROM sanctions "); bldr.append("WHERE ((name = ?) "); bldr.append("AND (ipaddress IS NOT NULL AND ipaddress = ?) OR (macaddress IS NOT NULL AND macaddress = ?)) "); bldr.append("AND closed = 0 "); bldr.append("ORDER BY id DESC"); statement = connection.prepareStatement(bldr.toString()); statement.setString(1, username); statement.setString(2, address); ResultSet result = statement.executeQuery(); // blocking op

But I feel like I am using AND wrong since it is already being used afterwards.

Perhaps I am over analyzing the syntax as I am know to do such things, just still difficult to understand.

Read full topic

item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:4, topic:548765”]What other advice can one offer than to simply learn how to use the JDBC library, and the SQL syntax? Presuming it’s SQLLITE or MySQL, but it’s verrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrry similar.[/quote]I think the biggest problem I am having is learning the syntax of SQL. The logic follows the same rules as every other language, but the way things are name and using multiple ORs after a WHERE can get confusing at times.

Read full topic

item.title: JDBC - Any knowledge is welcome
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

RiiPiiNFtW:

Going to try to teach myself how to efficiently use and successfully use JDBC with SQL and was wondering if anyone has any advice for me while I learn it.

What flavor of SQL?

Most SQL syntax is pretty simplistic and easy to grasp for most queries, however some more advanced ones can get a bit verbose.

There are tons of really nice APIs out there that help you manage all JDBC protocols with ease, jOOQ, SpringJDBC, Hibernate, ActiveJDBC, etc.

Read full topic
